summary: Micron has announced the commercial and industrial availability of its DDR5 DRAM specifically designed for next-generation Intel and AMD server and workstation platforms. This new DDR5 memory is expected to dramatically increase system performance by up to 85% over DDR4, catering to demanding AI, HPC, and data-intensive applications. Micron has been a key player in the development of DDR5 specifications and offers support through its Technology Enablement Program.

title: Direxion SOXL ETF: How To Trade This Leveraged Play On Semis (NYSEARCA:SOXL)
summary: This article discusses the Direxion Daily Semiconductor Bull 3X Shares ETF (SOXL), a 3X leveraged ETF on the semiconductor index. Despite SOXL being down 85% this year, the author advises against buying it immediately. The recommendation is to wait for signs of a bottom in the broader semiconductor index (SOXX) before initiating a position in SOXL.

title: HPE Is The First Big OEM To Adopt Ampere Computing Arm Chips
summary: HPE has announced its adoption of Ampere Computing's "Mystique" Altra Max Arm server chip in its standard ProLiant rack-mounted server, marking Ampere's first major OEM server maker partnership. This move, showcased with the ProLiant RL300 server, signifies HPE's renewed commitment to Arm-based processors after previous cautious ventures. The decision is driven by the Altra chips' deterministic performance and competitive price/performance, particularly for cloud-native workloads, positioning HPE to compete aggressively against Intel Xeon and AMD Epyc processors.

title: These software companies are unsung winners in the semiconductor industry
summary: This article highlights software companies like Synopsys Inc. (SNPS) and Cadence Design Systems Inc. (CDNS) as critical but often overlooked players in the semiconductor industry. These companies provide Electronic Design Automation (EDA) software, which is essential for chip design engineers. Despite the focus on chip giants, these software firms play a crucial role in enabling the broader semiconductor sector, especially amidst ongoing chip shortages.

title: Amid domestic semiconductor wave, Texas Instruments begins $30B build
summary: Texas Instruments has broken ground on an estimated $30 billion semiconductor manufacturing facility in Sherman, Texas, which is the largest private sector investment in Texas history. Production is slated to begin in 2025, creating up to 3,000 direct jobs and contributing to a nationwide effort to increase domestic chip manufacturing. This project aligns with a broader industry trend of expanding semiconductor fabrication in the U.S., driven by rising demand and supply chain challenges.

title: Gen-trepreneur Z is making its mark on the future of small business
summary: A Microsoft Store report "Small Business State of Mind" highlights how Generation Z is redefining entrepreneurship. Gen Z small business owners prioritize social good, work unconventional hours, and are using platforms like TikTok for business advice, aiming for early retirement rather than traditional corporate paths. The article emphasizes their unique perspective on work, success, and the future of small business, despite challenges like inflation and data security risks.

title: Best semiconductor ETFs in the UK 2023
summary: This article provides a comprehensive guide to semiconductor Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) available to UK investors, explaining what an ETF is, the history and importance of semiconductors, and how to evaluate investment opportunities in this sector. It highlights top-performing semiconductor ETFs, discusses the significance of UCITS, and addresses considerations for ESG-minded investors, particularly concerning ON Semiconductor.

title: Qualcomm maintains multiple sourcing strategy
summary: Qualcomm Inc. has stated it will maintain a multi-sourcing strategy for its chips, including advanced chips from two major suppliers, to ensure a stable supply amidst the pandemic and a slowing global economy. The company anticipates continued strong growth in 5G penetration and expects Wi-Fi 7 technology adoption to rapidly increase, with end products equipped with these chips by the end of this year.

title: Semiconductor ETF | ESG-screened investment in tech
summary: The VanEck Semiconductor UCITS ETF offers investors exposure to the semiconductor sector, targeting pure-play companies with at least half their revenues from semiconductors. It is Europe's first Semiconductor ETF, designed to capture growth from the "fourth industrial revolution" driven by semiconductor advancements, and is classified as SFDR Article 8 for promoting environmental and social characteristics. The ETF focuses on liquid semiconductor stocks globally and has a strategy that has been successful in the US since 2011, with $25 billion in AUM.

title: Nvidia Q1 FY2023 Earnings Report Preview: What To Look For
summary: Nvidia (NVDA) is set to report Q1 FY 2023 earnings, with analysts expecting growth in adjusted EPS and revenue, albeit at a slower pace. Investors will closely watch data center revenue, which is projected to accelerate and potentially surpass gaming revenue for the first time in FY 2023. The company is investing in AI chips to continue its growth trajectory, building on demand fueled by the pandemic.

title: Ex-Cisco chief John Chambers says Silicon Valley's in trouble, but it's not too late to fix things
summary: Former Cisco Systems CEO John Chambers believes Silicon Valley and the U.S. are entering one of their most difficult periods in his 46-year tech career. Despite the challenges, Chambers remains optimistic that solutions can be found. He shared these views with the Silicon Valley Business Journal, highlighting concerns for the region and the nation.

title: Nvidia pays $5.5m SEC fine over crypto-mining disclosures
summary: Nvidia agreed to pay a $5.5 million fine to the SEC for failing to adequately disclose revenue from crypto mining during two quarters in 2018. The SEC stated that Nvidia omitted information about surging demand from crypto miners while discussing how digital assets impacted other business lines. This lack of disclosure made Nvidia's financial results less predictable for investors.

title: Pave the Way for Next Wireless Breakthroughs
summary: This article discusses the accelerating pace of wireless innovation, focusing on the design and test challenges posed by next-generation wireless communication systems like 5G and satellite communications. It highlights key technological components such as wider bandwidths, higher-order modulation schemes, and multi-antenna techniques, and emphasizes the need for scalable and accurate test solutions to overcome these challenges. The author, Eric Hsu of Keysight Technologies Inc., explains how these advancements impact device performance and require sophisticated testing methods.

title: Intel Nabs Former AMD Exec Matt Poirier To Lead M&A Quest
summary: Intel has appointed former AMD executive Matt Poirier as senior vice president of corporate development, effective May 30, to lead its mergers and acquisitions strategy. Poirier, who previously focused on M&A at AMD and Xilinx, will report directly to CEO Pat Gelsinger. This move comes as Intel actively pursues acquisitions, including recent deals for Tower Semiconductor and Siru Innovations, and highlights the growing importance of M&A for Intel's expansion in various technology sectors.

title: New HP Chromebooks and Thin Clients Power Cloud-First Computing for Hybrid Work
summary: HP is launching new Chromebooks and Thin Clients, alongside software and device management solutions, tailored for hybrid work environments and cloud-first computing strategies. The new products, including the HP Elite c645 G2 and c640 G3 Chromebook Enterprises, and HP Elite t655 Thin Client, offer enhanced security, performance, and collaboration features designed to support mission-critical workers and IT teams. HP is also introducing HP Cloud Endpoint Manager for real-time thin client management and HP ThinPro 8.0 OS, emphasizing sustainability in its PC portfolio.

title: Advisors Are Powering Portfolios With Thematic ETFs
summary: Thematic ETFs, which invest in companies poised to benefit from long-term transformative changes, are increasingly being adopted by financial advisors as a replacement for traditional sector funds. These ETFs offer more precise exposure to growth trends like blockchain, emergent food, robotics, and electric vehicles. Asset managers are expanding their thematic ETF offerings, with BlackRock (iShares) recently launching two new products in this space, highlighting a growing conviction in the long-term benefits of thematic investing despite some recent market volatility.

title: HPE Creates Its Own AI Stack For Large Enterprises
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is expanding its AI software portfolio and leveraging its HPC hardware expertise to provide a comprehensive AI stack for large enterprises. This initiative includes a Machine Learning Development System that simplifies infrastructure management and facilitates collaboration for training models at scale, addressing the complexities faced by data scientists. Furthermore, HPE is promoting "swarm learning" to enable AI model training where data resides, crucial for privacy and compliance in industries like healthcare and banking.

title: Latest Oracle Exadata servers ascend to the cloud
summary: Oracle has announced the availability of its latest Exadata Cloud Infrastructure X9M appliance in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, marking the rollout of its newest generation of Exadata processors. This new service, based on AMD microprocessors, offers significant improvements in performance, throughput, and capacity without increased costs, allowing organizations to consolidate various database workloads. Oracle claims superior performance compared to AWS RDS and Azure SQL, with the service designed for scalable deployment both on-premises and across Oracle's expanding global cloud footprint.

title: Why dividend ETFs may not be worthwhile
summary: This article examines the viability of dividend ETFs, concluding that many are not worthwhile after accounting for taxes, fees, and capital distributions. The author discusses challenges like 30% dividend taxation for foreign investors in US ETFs, poor underlying stock performance in high-yield ETFs, and issues with capital distributions eroding value. Alternative options in Singapore, UK, and Hong Kong are also explored, but ultimately deemed insufficient, leading to the recommendation that investors build their own dividend portfolios.

title: The end of one-chip wonders: Why Nvidia, Intel and AMD’s valuations have experienced massive upheaval
summary: This article discusses the dramatic shift in market capitalization within the semiconductor industry over the past five years. Once dominant Intel has been surpassed by Nvidia, which is now valued as much as Intel and AMD combined, reflecting fundamental changes in how technology is used and specialized solutions. This upheaval highlights a significant transformation in the industry's landscape.

title: The end of one-chip wonders: Why Nvidia, Intel and AMD’s valuations have experienced massive upheaval
summary: The article discusses the dramatic shift in valuations among semiconductor companies, specifically Nvidia, Intel, and AMD. Five years ago, Intel's market capitalization surpassed Nvidia and AMD combined, but now Nvidia alone is worth more than the other two combined, reflecting significant changes in the semiconductor industry. This upheaval is attributed to evolving technology consumption patterns and companies specializing in new areas.

title: Do Penny Stocks Ever Make Money? Here Are 7 Success Stories
summary: This article highlights seven former penny stocks that achieved significant profitability and provided substantial returns for early investors. It demonstrates that while penny stocks are high-risk, those companies that eventually become profitable can offer life-changing gains. The article details the financial turnaround and stock performance of Advanced Micro Devices, BBQ Holdings, Syndax Pharmaceuticals, VAALCO Energy, Digital Turbine, eXp World Holdings, and The Joint Corp.

title: Which is the bigger company: AMD, Nvidia, or Intel?
summary: This article analyzes Intel, AMD, and Nvidia to determine which is the "bigger" company, looking beyond market capitalization to factors like employee count, revenue, product diversity, and market share. While Nvidia leads in market cap, sustained analysis reveals Intel to be the largest overall due to its revenue and employee numbers, despite AMD and Nvidia's significant recent growth. The article also touches on the unique advantage Intel holds with its chip manufacturing capabilities.

title: Technology ETF
summary: VanEck offers a suite of Technology ETFs that allow investors to gain exposure to disruptive and transformative megatrends such as semiconductors, spatial technology, hydrogen, esports, and cryptocurrency. These ETFs provide diversified exposure, potential for future winners through rules-based selection, regular rebalancing, and lower fees compared to actively managed funds. The article also details various risks associated with investing in Technology ETFs, including industry concentration, market risk, and liquidity risks.

title: The semiconductor decade: A trillion-dollar industry
summary: The global semiconductor industry is projected to reach a trillion-dollar valuation by 2030, driven by an average annual growth rate of 6 to 8 percent. Key growth areas include automotive, computation and data storage, and wireless technologies, with automotive expected to triple demand. Industry leaders are advised to strategically focus on R&D, manufacturing, and sourcing to capitalize on this expansion.

title: Synopsys Launches Industry's First Broad-Scale Cloud SaaS Solution to Transform Chip Development Landscape
summary: Synopsys has launched Synopsys Cloud, the industry's first broad-scale cloud Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution for chip development. This new model, optimized for electronic design automation (EDA) and deployed on Microsoft Azure, offers a pay-per-use approach to provide unparalleled flexibility and efficiency for complex chip designs. The collaboration with Microsoft aims to streamline access to compute and EDA resources, addressing the escalating demands of chip design and verification.

title: The Top 5: Biggest Automotive Semiconductor Manufacturers
summary: The automotive semiconductor market, valued at $43.6 billion in 2021, is projected to exceed $115 billion by 2030, driven by the growth of electric vehicles and autonomous technologies. This article identifies the top five automotive semiconductor manufacturers, excluding TSMC which dominates the foundry market, and details their market share, financial performance, and strategic investments. The leading companies are Infineon Technologies AG, NXP Semiconductors N.V., Renesas Electronics Corp., Texas Instruments, Inc., and STMicroelectronics N.V.

title: Nvidia considers teaming up with Intel on chip manufacturing
summary: Nvidia is in discussions with Intel about potentially using Intel as a foundry for manufacturing its chips. This consideration comes amid a global semiconductor chip shortage and Intel's efforts to become a major U.S. foundry supplier, despite the challenges of aligning technologies and business models between the companies. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang expressed openness to the idea, noting existing close collaboration between the firms.

title: Tackling Global Supply Chain Disruption
summary: This article discusses how Microsoft has addressed global supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic, focusing on leveraging technology for agility and resilience. It highlights digitizing factories, using AI/machine learning for data and logistics, and integrating sustainability. The article also introduces Microsoft's Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Insights as a solution for organizations seeking to build resilient supply chains.

title: NVIDIA Launches Omniverse for Developers: A Powerful and Collaborative Game Creation Environment
summary: NVIDIA has launched new Omniverse features for developers, creating a powerful and collaborative environment for game creation. This update streamlines game development by integrating AI and NVIDIA RTX tools, enabling real-time collaboration and enhancing character animation and asset management. Key new features include Omniverse Audio2Face, Omniverse Nucleus Cloud, Omniverse DeepSearch, and an Unreal Engine 5 Omniverse Connector.

title: Is It Finally Time to Start Buying Intel Stock?
summary: Intel, a pioneer in micro-processing, has seen its stock underperform competitors for years, but an ambitious makeover and new leadership may signal an attractive entry point for long-term investors. CEO Pat Gelsinger's plans for a massive $20 billion semiconductor plant in Ohio and other investments aim to restore Intel's market leadership. Despite investor skepticism reflected in its depressed stock price, Morningstar analysts see an appealing opportunity with a 27% discount to its fair value estimate and a 3.11% dividend yield.

title: EPAM Shares Continue to Fall on Ukraine Crisis & Russia Exit
summary: EPAM Systems' shares fell significantly due to the escalating Russia-Ukraine crisis and the company's decision to exit Russia. EPAM, with substantial exposure in Eastern Europe, announced it would discontinue services in Russia and offer humanitarian aid to Ukrainian employees, aligning with U.S. sanctions. The conflict is expected to impact the company's revenues and profitability due to its large workforce in the affected regions.

title: Nvidia hackers allegedly attempting to blackmail company into open-sourcing GPU drivers
summary: The Lapsus$ ransomware gang, responsible for a recent attack on Nvidia, is allegedly attempting to blackmail the company into open-sourcing its GPU drivers. The attackers have threatened to leak sensitive GPU files if Nvidia does not comply with their demands by a set deadline, which also included a previous request to remove mining hashrate limiters. Nvidia has confirmed a cybersecurity incident where employee credentials and proprietary information were stolen, but denies ransomware deployment.

title: Use WGMI to Enter the Crypto Economy
summary: The crypto economy is diversifying beyond direct Bitcoin ownership, with new ETFs like the Valkyrie Bitcoin Miners ETF (WGMI) offering access. WGMI focuses on bitcoin mining equities and is actively managed, allowing it to adapt to a nascent asset class with high growth potential. The ETF also incorporates a renewable energy overlay for its mining components, addressing environmental concerns associated with bitcoin mining.

title: Nvidia Posts Record Sales Amid Broad Chip Demand
summary: Nvidia Corp. reported record quarterly sales of $7.64 billion, a 53% increase from the previous year, and projected further growth. The graphics-chip maker also more than doubled its net income to $3 billion, surpassing Wall Street expectations for both profit and sales. This strong performance comes amidst broad chip demand, despite the company moving past its failed takeover bid for Arm Ltd.

title: Intel to Buy Israel’s Tower Semiconductor for $5.4 Billion
summary: Intel Corp. has agreed to acquire Israel’s Tower Semiconductor Ltd. for $5.4 billion as part of CEO Pat Gelsinger’s strategy to expand into the outsourced chip-manufacturing business. This acquisition aims to enhance Intel's expertise and customer base in the chip-foundry market, directly competing with industry leaders like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. The deal is expected to close in about 12 months and is a key part of Intel's broader investment cycle to modernize its factories and rebuild manufacturing capabilities.

title: Tower Semi deal won’t solve Intel’s margin issues, analysts say
summary: Intel's planned acquisition of Tower Semiconductor for $5.4 billion is unlikely to resolve its ongoing gross margin issues, according to analysts. While the deal aims to expand Intel's manufacturing capacity with new foundries, analysts suggest these additions focus on lower-margin production and will not help Intel become a leader in cutting-edge foundry technology. Wall Street has expressed dissatisfaction with Intel's declining gross margins, as CEO Pat Gelsinger invests in capacity building at the expense of immediate profitability.

title: SoftBank’s sale of Arm to Nvidia collapses, Arm to IPO
summary: The proposed sale of Arm Ltd by SoftBank Group Corp to U.S. chipmaker Nvidia Corp has collapsed due to regulatory hurdles and scrutiny from various international bodies. Instead of the sale, which was valued at up to $80 billion, Arm will now plan for an initial public offering (IPO). The deal faced opposition from U.S., British, EU, and Chinese regulators over concerns about competition, pricing, and innovation in vital chip markets.

title: Alphabet eyes $2 trillion value after blowout results
summary: Alphabet Inc. is on the verge of joining Apple and Microsoft in the $2 trillion market valuation club after a strong quarterly report led to an over 8% surge in its shares. The company also announced a 20-to-1 stock split, aiming to make shares more accessible to retail investors. At least 20 brokerages raised their price targets on Alphabet's stock.

title: ETF Flows Cool Off as Stocks Stumble Out of the Gate
summary: January 2022 saw a significant cool-off in ETF flows and a stumble in stock markets globally, marking the worst monthly showing for the Morningstar Global Markets Index since March 2020. Fixed-income ETFs also experienced outflows, their first since March 2020, as investors reallocated their money amidst interest rate hike predictions and a strong performance from the energy sector. Vanguard dominated ETF provider flows, while drug and digital-asset focused ETFs appeared cheap, reflecting market turbulence and potential undervaluation.

title: Cadence Platform Accelerates Microchip’s Data Center Solutions SoC Development
summary: Microchip Technology Inc. has adopted Cadence's Palladium Z2 Enterprise Emulation Platform for the development of its next-generation ASIC products, specifically targeting high-performance and scalable SoC solutions for data centers. The Palladium Z2 platform offers Microchip 2X better emulation capacity and 1.5X greater performance, alongside seamless integration with Cadence's Protium Enterprise Prototyping system. This adoption significantly accelerates Microchip's time-to-market and quality requirements for complex multi-chip systems.

title: Reference design offers wireless docking over Wi-Fi 6E for PCs
summary: Synaptics Incorporated has introduced Gemini, a reference design that offers wireless docking over Wi-Fi 6E for PCs, claiming it's the world's first true Wi-Fi 6/6E wireless docking experience for laptops. This technology enables full dual-4K display capability and ultra-low latency, comparable to wired connections, and integrates hardware and software components like the BCM43752 Wi-Fi 6/6E radio and DL-1950 video interface IC. While initially focused on PC docking, Gemini's applications extend to tablets, gaming, and VR, with analyst Patrick Moorhead highlighting its potential to revolutionize connectivity in hybrid work environments.

title: Western Digital Taps Semiconductor Veteran for CFO Job
summary: Western Digital has appointed Wissam Jabre, a semiconductor industry veteran, as its new Chief Financial Officer. This move aligns with the hard-drive manufacturer's strategy to expand its memory-chip business. Mr. Jabre previously served as CFO at Dialog Semiconductor PLC and held finance roles at Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and Freescale Semiconductor Inc.

title: Silicon Labs Integrates AI/ML Acceleration in Low-power Wireless SoCs
summary: Silicon Labs has released two new families of wireless SoCs, BG24 and MG24, that integrate AI/ML accelerators for low-power IoT edge processing. These SoCs support a wide range of protocols and offer significant power reduction and speed increase for AI/ML applications. The company also introduced a software platform to aid developers in deploying AI/ML algorithms for various use cases, including smart home applications and medical devices.

title: These 3 ETFs let you play the hot semiconductor sector, where Nvidia, Micron, AMD and others are growing sales rapidly
summary: This article suggests that semiconductor stocks remain an excellent investment area despite rising interest rates, highlighting the robust sales growth of companies like Nvidia, Micron, and AMD. It points to three ETFs that allow investors to capitalize on this hot sector, which has significantly outperformed the S&P 500 and Nasdaq over the past 15 years. The positive outlook was reinforced by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.'s strong Q4 sales and earnings report and substantial planned capital expenditures for 2022.

title: These 3 ETFs let you play the hot semiconductor sector, where Nvidia, Micron, AMD and others are growing sales rapidly
summary: The article suggests that the semiconductor sector remains a strong investment area, even with rising interest rates impacting other tech stocks. It highlights the strong performance of chip exchange-traded funds (ETFs) over the past 15 years, outperforming both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq. This positive outlook is further supported by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.'s impressive fourth-quarter results and significant capital expenditure plans for 2022.

title: These 3 ETFs let you play the hot semiconductor sector, where Nvidia, Micron, AMD and others are growing sales rapidly
summary: This article highlights three ETFs that allow investors to gain exposure to the rapidly growing semiconductor sector, which includes companies like Nvidia, Micron, and AMD. Despite concerns about rising interest rates, the semiconductor industry continues to show strong growth, as evidenced by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.'s impressive Q4 sales and earnings report. The chip-focused exchange-traded funds have significantly outperformed both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq over the past 15 years.

title: These 3 ETFs let you play the hot semiconductor sector, where Nvidia, Micron, AMD and others are growing sales rapidly
summary: This article discusses the continued growth potential of the semiconductor sector and how investors can capitalize on it through ETFs. Despite concerns about rising interest rates affecting tech stocks, chipmakers are demonstrating strong sales growth. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) reported significant increases in its fourth-quarter sales and earnings, signaling a robust outlook for the industry.

title: These 3 ETFs let you play the hot semiconductor sector, where Nvidia, Micron, AMD and others are growing sales rapidly
summary: This article highlights three ETFs that offer investors exposure to the rapidly growing semiconductor sector, featuring companies like Nvidia, Micron, and AMD. The chip-focused exchange-traded funds have significantly outperformed the S&P 500 and Nasdaq over the past 15 years, indicating their strong performance potential despite market pressures. The article also mentions Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) reporting robust fourth-quarter sales and earnings, reinforcing the sector's positive outlook.

title: These 3 ETFs let you play the hot semiconductor sector, where Nvidia, Micron, AMD and others are growing sales rapidly
summary: This article discusses the semiconductor sector as a potentially excellent area for investors, even amidst rising interest rates. It highlights how chip exchange-traded funds (ETFs) have significantly outperformed major benchmarks. The sector's growth is exemplified by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.'s strong fourth-quarter results and substantial capital expenditure plans for 2022.

title: Maze Therapeutics Nets $190M to Propel Precision Medicine Programs
summary: Maze Therapeutics secured $190 million in financing to advance its precision medicine pipeline, which includes nine programs. The company, founded in 2019, focuses on developing treatments for diseases like Pompe disease, Phenylketonuria, ALS, and chronic kidney disease, leveraging insights from human genetics. Matrix Capital Management led the new investment round, and Andy Tran from Matrix Capital Management joined Maze's board.

title: Hesai Technology showcased new automotive-grade hybrid solid-state Lidar AT128
summary: Hesai Technology showcased its new automotive-grade hybrid solid-state lidar AT128 at CES 2022. This long-range sensor is designed for L3+ ADAS applications in mass production vehicles, featuring image-level resolution, superior ranging capability, and automotive-grade reliability, with mass production slated for 2022. Hesai also unveiled the QT128, a short-range lidar aimed at L4 applications, entering mass production in Q1 2023.

title: AMD and GlobalFoundries Renew their Wafer Supply Agreement to increase their wafer commitments
summary: AMD and GlobalFoundries have renewed their wafer supply agreement, extending it to 2025 and increasing the confirmed spending by $500 million to a total of $2.1 billion. This agreement secures more guaranteed manufacturing capacity for AMD, primarily for 12nm and 14nm wafers. The extension ensures GlobalFoundries continues to supply AMD with critical components for its Ryzen and EPYC processors.

title: Intel Apologizes for Asking Suppliers to Avoid Xinjiang
summary: Intel Corp. issued an apology after asking its suppliers to avoid sourcing goods from Xinjiang, a region where the Chinese government is accused of human rights abuses. This request, made to comply with U.S. regulations, drew sharp criticism from Chinese state media and prompted calls for boycotts of Intel products. The incident highlights the growing tensions between foreign companies and China over the Xinjiang issue.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Desktop computers and All-in-One PCs
summary: HP offers a wide range of desktop computers and All-in-One PCs designed for various uses, including work, entertainment, gaming, and creative tasks. The article highlights new AI PC models like the HP OmniDesk and OmniStudio X, alongside established lines such as HP Pavilion, Envy, OMEN, and VICTUS, detailing their specifications and intended applications. Customers can filter choices by use case, series, operating system, product type, and screen size to find the perfect device.

title: Intel to invest $7 billion in new plant in Malaysia, creating 9,000 jobs
summary: Intel Chief Executive Pat Gelsinger announced a $7 billion investment to build a new chip-packaging and testing factory in Malaysia, creating over 4,000 Intel jobs and more than 5,000 construction jobs. This expansion aims to address the global semiconductor shortage, which Gelsinger expects to persist into 2023. The new advanced packaging facility is projected to begin production in 2024.

title: Infographic: Highlights of 3M Company’s Q3 2021 earnings report
summary: Shares of The 3M Company (NYSE: MMM) rebounded last week after reporting stronger-than-expected Q3 2021 financial results. The company's adjusted earnings were flat year-over-year at $2.45 per share but topped expectations, while net sales increased 7% to $8.94 billion. Management narrowed its fiscal 2021 earnings guidance and expects net sales to grow 9-10%.

title: Regulators in US, UK, EU All Alarmed By Chip Maker Nvidia’s $40B Deal to Buy Chip Designer
summary: Regulators in the U.S., U.K., and E.U. are expressing alarm over Nvidia Corporation's $40 billion proposed acquisition of chip designer Arm Ltd. The U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has filed a lawsuit to block the deal, citing concerns that it would grant Nvidia too much power and stifle competition and innovation in the semiconductor industry. Nvidia, however, maintains that the merger would benefit the industry, promote competition, and preserve Arm's open licensing model.

title: Synopsys Extends Industry Leadership as Customers Surpass 500 Tapeouts Using Flagship Fusion Compiler Solution
summary: Synopsys announced that its flagship Fusion Compiler RTL-to-GDSII solution has been used for over 500 tapeouts since its general availability in 2019. Customers leveraging Fusion Compiler have reported significant performance improvements, including up to 20% better performance, 15% lower power, and 5% smaller area compared to competitive solutions. The solution has been adopted by leading semiconductor companies for designs ranging from 40nm to 3nm across key markets like 5G mobile, HPC, AI, and hyperscale data centers.

title: U.S. sues to block Nvidia’s $40-billion chip takeover of Arm
summary: U.S. antitrust officials have sued to block Nvidia's proposed $40-billion acquisition of Arm Ltd., citing concerns that the deal would stifle innovation and undermine competition in the semiconductor industry. The Federal Trade Commission argues that the merger would grant Nvidia excessive control over chip designs widely used across various technologies. The acquisition, initially valued at $40 billion in September 2020, has faced regulatory hurdles globally due to Arm's critical role as a technology licensor to hundreds of companies including Nvidia's rivals.

title: Amazon's cloud unit launches new chips to take on Intel, Nvidia
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) has introduced two new custom computing chips, Graviton3 and Trainium, aimed at competing with offerings from Intel, AMD, and Nvidia. AWS claims its new chips offer better performance per dollar and lower costs for machine learning model training compared to its rivals. This move signals AWS's continued drive to develop its own hardware and intensify competition in the cloud computing and chip markets.

title: MediaTek, AMD co-developed Wi-Fi 6E modules to power laptops, desktops from 2022
summary: MediaTek and AMD have partnered to develop Wi-Fi 6E modules, the AMD RZ600 Series, which integrate MediaTek’s Filogic 330P chipset. These modules, designed to power AMD Ryzen-series laptops and desktops starting in 2022, aim to provide seamless connectivity, high throughput, and extended battery life. The Filogic 330P chipset supports Wi-Fi 6 (2.4/5GHz), 6E (6GHz band), and Bluetooth 5.2, also incorporating MediaTek’s power amplifier and low noise amplifier technology.

title: Sabre (SABR) Collaborates With Mexico's Calafia Airlines
summary: Sabre Corporation (SABR) has entered into a multi-year distribution partnership with Mexico's Calafia Airlines, allowing the airline to distribute its flights and services to travel agencies in the United States and other regions through Sabre's travel marketplace. This collaboration aims to accelerate Calafia Airlines' revenue growth and expand its global reach, while also helping Sabre strengthen its customer share in the Airlines Solutions segment. The deal is part of Sabre's broader strategy to upgrade its technology and support the recovery of the travel industry, following several other strategic partnerships with global airlines and hotel chains.

title: Podcast: Rivian's blockbuster IPO is a triumph of entrepreneurship
summary: This podcast episode discusses Rivian's blockbuster $12 billion IPO, highlighting it as a significant entrepreneurial achievement. It also touches on whether a deal with Meta could help AMD compete more effectively with Intel. The article celebrates Rivian's success and explores potential shifts in the tech industry.

title: Supermicro Enhances Broadest Portfolio of Edge to Cloud AI Systems with Accelerated Inferencing and New Intelligent Fabric Support
summary: Supermicro announced enhancements to its AI GPU server portfolio, integrating new NVIDIA Ampere-family GPUs to deliver up to 10x faster AI inference performance and 3x faster training. These systems are designed for a wide range of applications from edge computing to cloud environments, critical for uses like autonomous driving, video streaming, and cloud gaming. Supermicro also introduced its Universal GPU Platform and systems supporting the new NVIDIA Quantum-2 InfiniBand product line, alongside optimized solutions for NVIDIA Omniverse Enterprise.

title: AMD lands Meta as customer and takes on Nvidia, sending shares up 11%
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) shares rose 11% after announcing Meta Platforms Inc. as a new data center chip customer, intensifying its competition with Intel. AMD also unveiled new chips, including the MI200 for AI and machine learning to challenge Nvidia, and the Bergamo processor for cloud computing to compete with Ampere Computing. These strategic moves bolster AMD's market position against larger rivals and secure its presence with major cloud providers.

title: AMD shares close up 10% after company wins Meta partnership, announces new chips
summary: AMD shares surged 10% after the company announced a partnership with Meta (formerly Facebook) as a chip customer and unveiled a new range of chips at its Accelerated Data Center Premiere event. This move strengthens AMD's position against competitors like Intel, as the company continues to gain market share with its data center chip sales experiencing significant growth. Additional details about the Meta partnership are expected to be revealed later in the week at the Open Compute Project summit.

title: Europe Photomask Market New Study Offers Insights up to 2028|
summary: This article announces a new study on the Europe Photomask Market, offering insights up to 2028. Key players like Toppan Photomasks and Dai Nippon Printing Co. Ltd. are highlighted. The report covers growth elements, trends, forecasts, size, share, demand, and distribution, with a focus on the impact of IoT and semiconductor demands.

title: Intel Loses Ground to AMD as Demand for Chromebook Chips Wanes
summary: Intel Corp. lost over 2 percentage points of market share to Advanced Micro Devices Inc. in the third quarter of 2021, a setback driven primarily by a sharp decline in demand for chips used in low-end notebooks like Chromebooks. AMD now accounts for 24.6% of personal-computer processor sales, up from 22.5% a year prior, as Intel's technology edge erodes.

title: ECE alumnus Kevin Lepak receives one of chip maker AMD’s highest honors
summary: Kevin Lepak, an alumnus of Electrical & Computer Engineering at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, has been appointed as an AMD Corporate Fellow, one of the company's highest honors. This recognition is for his critical role in designing AMD's next-generation processors, including EPYC CPUs and Instinct accelerators, and his leadership in system-on-chip design and memory performance. Lepak's contributions have significantly impacted AMD's leadership in the data center market and its high-performance product roadmap.
source: College of Engineering | University of Wisconsin-Madison
source_domain: College of Engineering | University of Wisconsin-Madison

title: Chipmaker GlobalFoundries valued at $26 bln in lackluster Nasdaq debut
summary: GlobalFoundries Inc. made a lackluster Nasdaq debut, with shares opening flat and finishing slightly below its IPO price, valuing the chipmaker at approximately $26 billion. Despite raising $2.6 billion, the company faces lower gross margins compared to competitors, though it plans significant investments to boost capacity and future margins amid a global chip shortage. CEO Thomas Caulfield expects demand to remain high for years, with acute shortages potentially easing in 2023.

title: AMD Grows Revenue In Sixth Straight Quarter Reveal Q3 2021 Results
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ:AMD) reported significant revenue growth for its third fiscal quarter of 2021, marking its sixth consecutive quarter of revenue increase, driven primarily by its Enterprise, Embedded and Semi-custom segment. The company recorded $4.3 billion in net sales, representing a 54% annual and 12% sequential growth, with strong contributions from data center and custom-design chips. Despite a sequential drop in cash flows due to investments in long-term supply chain capacity, AMD doubled its operating income and achieved a 78% annual net income growth, with projections for continued revenue and gross margin improvement in the current quarter.

title: AMD sales rise 54% on strong demand for chips for servers and game consoles
summary: AMD reported strong third-quarter earnings, beating analyst expectations for both revenue and EPS, driven by high demand for its chips in PCs, servers, and game consoles. The company also issued a robust forecast for the fourth quarter, expecting continued growth in server and semi-custom segments amidst ongoing chip shortages. AMD's strategic acquisition of Xilinx is proceeding, aiming to strengthen its position in the data center market.

title: Beelink SER3 Review – A good AMD Ryzen 7 mini PC… after tweaks
summary: This review examines the Beelink SER3 mini PC featuring an AMD Ryzen 7 3750H processor, highlighting that while its out-of-the-box performance is satisfactory, significant improvements can be achieved through BIOS tweaks, including memory overclocking and power scheme adjustments. The article details hardware specifications, performance benchmarks on Windows and Ubuntu, eGPU capabilities, power consumption, and gaming performance after optimization. It concludes that with a few specific changes, the SER3 offers impressive performance for its price, despite some initial limitations like single-channel memory.

title: Apple unveils game-changing MacBook Pro
summary: Apple has unveiled a completely reimagined MacBook Pro powered by the new M1 Pro and M1 Max chips, available in 14- and 16-inch models. These new laptops offer extraordinary performance, unprecedented battery life, and advanced features like a Liquid Retina XDR display, improved camera and audio systems, and extensive connectivity, marking a significant leap for professional users. The MacBooks are designed for various professionals, offer remarkable power efficiency, and feature an environmentally conscious design with recycled materials.

title: ASML Holding: On Sentiment, Semiconductors & Sanity
summary: This article discusses ASML Holding N.V. (Nasdaq: ASML), a critical player in the semiconductor equipment market, highlighting its unique extreme ultraviolet (EUV) and deep ultraviolet (DUV) lithography technologies. Despite strong fundamental performance, including significant revenue growth and high gross margins, the stock recently experienced a 20% drop due to negative investor sentiment and inflation fears, rather than any issues with its business operations. The author argues that Wall Street's current focus on sentiment over fundamentals presents a buying opportunity for growth investors.

title: NXP selects AWS to host chip design & verification systems
summary: NXP Semiconductors has chosen AWS as its primary cloud provider for electronic design automation (EDA) workloads, migrating the majority of its EDA systems to AWS infrastructure. This move aims to leverage AWS's scalable compute power to accelerate chip design and verification processes, reduce costs, and minimize scheduling risks. The partnership expands on previous collaborations between NXP and AWS, focusing on accelerating semiconductor innovation and bringing new designs to market faster.

title: Understanding the Buzz Around the BUZZ ETF
summary: The article discusses the VanEck Vectors Social Sentiment ETF (BUZZ), which debuted in March 2021 and capitalizes on the "meme stock" phenomenon. It examines BUZZ's methodology, noting that its longer lookback period means it doesn't solely focus on highly speculative meme stocks like GameStop and AMC. Instead, BUZZ's portfolio includes quality names like AMD, Apple, Nvidia, and Pfizer, and exhibits low single-stock risk.

title: Highest Density SuperBlade® Server for HPC Applications
summary: Supermicro's SuperBlade® server solutions offer high density and efficiency for HPC, enterprise cloud, and other demanding applications. Available in 8U, 6U, and 4U enclosures, these systems support advanced processors from Intel and AMD, high-speed networking, and various storage options, alongside resource-saving architecture for optimal TCO. The article highlights successful deployments by companies like HEROZ and Korea Hydro and Nuclear Power, and provides extensive details on features and configurations.

title: Integra LifeSciences enhances multicloud capability with OCI, achieves 90% time savings and boosts IT efficiency
summary: Integra LifeSciences significantly improved its IT efficiency and multicloud capabilities by migrating its mission-critical E-Business Suite applications to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). This move resulted in a 90% time savings for daily sales invoice reports and a reduction of nightly data analytics processing from 8.5 to 3.5 hours, leveraging OCI's high-performance platform and its interconnection with Microsoft Azure. The company also enhanced business resiliency and gained proactive performance insights, solidifying a strategic position for future growth.

title: CORSAIR Debuts their new XENEON 32QHD165 Gaming Monitor, featuring an ultra-slim 32-inch QHD screen
summary: CORSAIR has launched its new XENEON 32QHD165 Gaming Monitor, featuring a 32-inch QHD IPS LED screen with a 165Hz refresh rate and compatibility with AMD FreeSync Premium and NVIDIA G-SYNC. The monitor is designed for gamers and creators, offering excellent color accuracy, HDR400 support, and integration with CORSAIR iCUE and Elgato Stream Deck software. It also boasts a versatile design with a unique stand featuring a 1/4" threading for mounting accessories and comprehensive connectivity options.

title: Download AMD Cleanup Utility 1.0.0.1 for Windows
summary: The AMD Cleanup Utility is a free tool designed to remove old AMD drivers and applications, improving system performance by clearing out unnecessary files and registry entries. It supports Windows 7 to Windows 10 and is recommended for users to run in safe mode for optimal results. The utility helps users maintain their PCs by simplifying the removal process of graphics drivers and related software.

title: Samsung to make Tesla’s HW 4.0 self-driving auto chip
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. has won the contract to manufacture Tesla Inc.'s next-generation hardware 4 (HW 4.0) chip for its autonomous driving technology, beating out TSMC. Samsung plans to mass-produce the HW 4.0 chip using 7-nanometer processing technology, ensuring higher production yields and stable functions for Tesla's upcoming vehicles like the Cybertruck. This partnership strengthens Samsung's position in the global foundry market as it competes with TSMC and expands its collaborations with other tech giants like Google and Amazon.

title: Applied Materials improves die-to-wafer and wafer-to-wafer bonding
summary: Applied Materials has announced advancements in die-to-wafer and wafer-to-wafer bonding technologies to improve heterogeneous chip design and integration. This includes enhanced software modeling and simulation, a partnership with BE Semiconductor Industries (Besi) for die-based hybrid bonding equipment, and a joint development agreement with EV Group (EVG) focusing on wafer bonding and related processes. Additionally, Applied Materials' acquisition of Tango Systems has yielded benefits for panel-level processing.

title: Look for PCIe 5.0, NVMe 2.0 to boost storage performance
summary: Enterprises requiring high-performance storage for AI and ML workloads should anticipate new products utilizing PCIe 5.0 and NVMe 2.0 specifications. PCIe 5.0 doubles data rates, and NVMe 2.0 introduces command sets for key-value (KV) and Zoned Namespace (ZNS) technologies, though product availability will lag, with software changes needed to fully leverage NVMe 2.0's benefits.

title: NVIDIA Stock Price and Forecast: Why is NVDA stock going up?
summary: NVIDIA stock continues to rise, hitting new all-time highs despite broader market nervousness ahead of the Jackson Hole symposium. A Reuters report about the US Department of Energy purchasing a supercomputer with Nvidia chips is cited as a catalyst. The article also touches on concerns from the UK's Competition and Markets Authority regarding Nvidia's proposed acquisition of ARM.

title: Synopsys' AI-Assisted EDA Tools Aim To Cut GPU Design Costs in Half
summary: Synopsys' new AI-assisted Electronic Design Automation (EDA) tools promise to significantly reduce the cost and time required for chip design, particularly for GPUs. The DSO.ai platform can optimize various aspects of chip design, potentially cutting development time from 24 months to 24 weeks and reducing costs by as much as 50%. Companies like Samsung, Google, and Nvidia are already adopting this technology, which could also democratize chip development for smaller firms.

title: Intel Lands Pentagon Deal to Support Domestic Chip Making
summary: Intel Corp. has secured a deal with the Pentagon to provide commercial foundry services as part of the Rapid Assured Microelectronics Prototypes - Commercial (RAMP-C) program. This initiative aims to bolster domestic design and production of advanced microchips, addressing a global chip shortage and supporting the U.S. government's long-term national security needs. Intel will join other companies like IBM and Synopsys in this effort, with plans to invest $20 billion in new factories in Arizona.
banner_image: Photo: Edwin Cheng for The Wall Street Journal

title: Niche chip maker SkyWater plays key role in U.S. supply strategy
summary: SkyWater Technology Inc., a niche U.S. chip manufacturer, is playing a crucial role in the Biden administration's strategy to bolster domestic semiconductor supply chains and reduce reliance on foreign production, particularly from Taiwan. Despite its smaller size compared to industry giants, SkyWater's status as the only U.S. investor-owned fab and its advanced 3-D chip stacking technology, backed by significant military funding, position it as a key player in the intensifying U.S.-China competition for technological supremacy. The article highlights the global push by various nations, including the U.S., Europe, and Japan, to strengthen their domestic chip industries amidst supply chain disruptions and geopolitical concerns, though some experts question the efficacy of government interventions.

title: Intel CEO Calls Chip Maker ‘Willing Buyer’ as Semiconductor Industry Consolidates
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger has stated that the company is a "willing buyer" as the semiconductor industry consolidates. He plans to use mergers and acquisitions to support Intel's revival strategy. Gelsinger expects consolidation to continue in the industry and sees Intel as a key consolidator.

title: AMD Set To Become TSMC’s 2nd Largest Customer – Apple Car Chip Production Rumored For China
summary: AMD is projected to become TSMC's second-largest customer, behind Apple, due to strong growth across its chip segments, especially EPYC server products. This increased demand from AMD, Apple, and MediaTek is accelerating order flows for TSMC's 3nm process. Additionally, there are rumors that automotive chip production for an "Apple Car" might take place at TSMC's Nanjing facility using older 28nm process nodes.

title: Rambus Outs HBM3 Details: 1.075 TBps of Bandwidth, 16 Channels, 16-Hi Stacks
summary: Rambus has unveiled new details about its HBM3-ready combined PHY and memory controller, revealing specifications that promise a significant leap in memory performance. The new HBM3 standard could achieve up to 8.4 Gbps-per-pin, 1.075 TB/s of throughput, and support for 16 channels and 16-Hi memory stacks, more than doubling the capacity and bandwidth of HBM2E. These advancements are expected to radically speed up future GPUs and SoCs, with the first chips leveraging this design anticipated in late 2022 or early 2023.

title: Nvidia earnings will be a data-center show, but don’t miss the software on the side stage
summary: Nvidia's upcoming second-quarter earnings report is expected to heavily feature data-center sales, with analysts predicting a significant rise in server-chip sales. However, the article highlights the increasing importance of Nvidia's software in its overall valuation, suggesting it should be compared more with software companies. While hardware is key, the software supporting Nvidia's graphics processing chips is a critical, often overlooked, aspect of its market position.

title: Samsung Is Using AI to Design Its Next Exynos Chipset for Smartphones
summary: Samsung is reportedly leveraging artificial intelligence, specifically Synopsys' DSO.ai tool, to design its next Exynos chipsets for smartphones. This AI-driven approach aims to automate and accelerate the complex chip development process, potentially improving performance and power efficiency. While Samsung has not confirmed which future products, such as the rumored Exynos 2200, will utilize these AI-designed chips, industry experts suggest AI is well-suited for arranging billions of transistors on a chip.

title: 5 reasons why AMD stock could rally more than 20% from here, according to Bank of America analyst
summary: A Bank of America analyst, Vivek Arya, believes AMD stock could rally more than 20% due to several factors, including the company's potential to expand gross margins and double earnings per share within the next two to three years. This projection comes after AMD shares have already seen a significant surge of over 50% in the last three months, and the stock is considered undervalued compared to other tech companies with similar growth.

title: Samsung Has Its Own AI-Designed Chip. Soon, Others Will Too
summary: Samsung is utilizing AI-designed chips developed with Synopsys's new software, DSO.ai, for its Exynos processors, marking a significant step in the semiconductor industry. This innovative approach, also being explored by companies like Google, Nvidia, and IBM, leverages reinforcement learning to automate and accelerate the complex chip design process, potentially leading to novel designs and improved performance. While AI-driven design is currently expensive, experts anticipate it will become a standard tool in the future.

title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang will receive the chip industry's top award
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is being recognized with the Semiconductor Industry Association's prestigious Robert Noyce Award. The award acknowledges Nvidia's significant contributions across gaming, self-driving cars, and scientific computing. Huang will receive the honor at a dinner ceremony in November.

title: NVIDIA maintains dominant position in 2020 market for AI processors for cloud and data center
summary: NVIDIA maintained its dominant position in the 2020 global market for AI processors used in cloud and data centers, holding an 80.6% share of global revenue. The company generated $3.2 billion in cloud and data center AI processor revenue, up from $1.8 billion in 2019, primarily due to its leadership in GPU-derived chips. Omdia predicts that alternative suppliers will gain significant market share in the coming years despite NVIDIA's current advantage.

title: Microchip Technology sees record sales as computer chip supply issues persist
summary: Microchip Technology (MCHP) reported record-setting sales at the beginning of its 2022 fiscal year, driven by the ongoing global demand for computer chips. CEO Ganesh Moorthy indicated that the entire semiconductor supply chain remains constrained, suggesting that chip shortages will extend into 2022. The company, based in Chandler, is experiencing strong demand amidst an industry-wide supply crunch.

title: AMD Trying To Increase Worldwide Semiconductor Availability
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) is making significant investments across its supply chain to increase worldwide semiconductor availability amidst a global chip shortage. The company is responding to the surge in demand for PCs, re-energized by remote work and learning during the pandemic, and is working to bridge the gap in semiconductor supply which is expected to last until at least 2023. AMD's Corporate Vice President, David McAfee, highlighted their efforts to source additional capacity and noted the challenge of the limited number of specialized chip fabrication facilities globally.

title: Hey Intel, AMD’s CEO is also ready to ‘fight for every socket,’ while producing strong growth
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su echoed Intel's pledge to "fight for every socket" in the crucial data-center market, demonstrating confidence as AMD continues strong growth. AMD is outperforming Intel by increasing its annual guidance and seeing data-center sales top 20% of its revenue.

title: Hey Intel, AMD’s CEO is also ready to ‘fight for every socket,’ while producing strong growth
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su responded to Intel's promise to "fight for every socket" by stating AMD is also ready for the competition. This comes as AMD demonstrates strong growth, particularly with data-center sales exceeding 20% of its revenue, leading to an increase in its annual guidance. Su's comments highlight the escalating rivalry in the chip market, particularly in the crucial data-center segment.

title: Intel to build Qualcomm chips, aims to catch foundry rivals by 2025
summary: Intel announced its factories will begin building chips for Qualcomm and Amazon, aiming to regain its leadership in chip manufacturing by 2025 against rivals like TSMC and Samsung. The company outlined a new roadmap with five chipmaking technologies and a revised naming scheme to reflect its competitive standing. This move signifies Intel's commitment to overcoming past delays and establishing itself as a leading foundry.

title: GlobalFoundries' second fab sure to bring more jobs, tech prestige to Capital Region
summary: GlobalFoundries plans to build a second chip manufacturing facility, Fab 8.2, in Saratoga County, which is expected to cost over $10 billion and create 1,000 new jobs. This expansion is contingent on federal funding from the U.S. Innovation and Competition Act, which aims to boost U.S. semiconductor manufacturing amidst a global chip shortage. The project, along with an existing Fab 8 expansion, will significantly increase chip output and solidify the Capital Region's role in the global tech industry.

title: Intel CEO Says Chip Shortage Could Stretch Into 2023
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger believes the global semiconductor shortage could extend into 2023, joining a growing consensus that supply chain disruptions will persist. The shortage is impacting various industries, leading to rising prices and production delays for goods ranging from consumer gadgets to automobiles. While some easing is expected later this year, a full return to supply-and-demand balance in the semiconductor industry could take one to two years due to the time required to build manufacturing capacity.

title: Intel in talks to buy GlobalFoundries for about $30 billion - WSJ
summary: Intel Corp is reportedly in talks to acquire semiconductor manufacturer GlobalFoundries Inc for approximately $30 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. This potential deal comes amid a global semiconductor shortage and could help Intel significantly ramp up chip production, although GlobalFoundries has denied direct discussions with Intel. The acquisition could also raise antitrust questions given GlobalFoundries' history with AMD.

title: Intel is in talks to buy GlobalFoundries for about $30 billion
summary: Intel is reportedly in discussions to acquire GlobalFoundries for approximately $30 billion, a move that would significantly boost Intel's strategy to become a major contract chip manufacturer. This potential acquisition aligns with Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger's push to expand chip-making capabilities for other companies, a market currently dominated by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. The deal, if it materializes, would be Intel's largest acquisition ever, although GlobalFoundries is also considering an initial public offering.

title: Intel exploring deal to buy US chipmaker GlobalFoundries for $30B
summary: Intel Corp. is reportedly in talks to acquire chipmaker GlobalFoundries Inc. for up to $30 billion, which would be Intel's largest acquisition to date. The potential deal aligns with Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger's strategy to bolster the company's chip production capabilities and compete with industry leaders like TSMC. Analysts note the acquisition could offer immediate benefits to Intel by providing access to more fabs, while GlobalFoundries' owners would secure a significant payday without the uncertainty of an IPO.

title: AMD directors dodge shareholder derivative suit over board diversity
summary: A federal judge in California dismissed a shareholder lawsuit against Advanced Micro Devices Inc.'s board, which alleged breach of duty for not including a Black director. The judge ruled that the lawsuit failed to provide specific allegations as to why it would have been futile to demand action directly from the board before suing. This dismissal is one of several similar cases filed since last summer concerning board diversity, with most plaintiffs receiving permission to refile.

title: TSMC Wins Intel Order For Two 3nm CPUs To Regain Market Share Lost To AMD
summary: TSMC has secured an order from Intel to produce two 3nm CPUs, signaling Intel's strategy to regain market share lost to AMD, particularly in notebooks and data centers. This move marks a significant shift for Intel, which has historically relied on its own manufacturing facilities, and indicates a larger 3nm chip order for Intel than for Apple. Mass production for TSMC's 3nm process is expected to begin next year, with commercial output of Intel's chips following in 2023.

title: Focus: Qualcomm's new CEO eyes dominance in the laptop markets
summary: Qualcomm's new CEO, Cristiano Amon, plans to challenge Apple's dominance in the laptop market by developing energy-efficient chips with the help of former Apple chip architects. The company is also focusing on revenue growth from China for its smartphone chip business despite political tensions and aims to leverage its Nuvia acquisition to push 5G connectivity into laptops, providing custom-designed chips to compete with Apple. Amon also faces the challenge of potentially losing Apple as a modem chip customer and improving Qualcomm's brand recognition among consumers.

title: Qualcomm's new CEO eyes dominance in laptop markets
summary: Qualcomm's new CEO, Cristiano Amon, aims to dominate the laptop chip market by next year, challenging Apple's energy-efficient chips with custom-designed processors. The company plans to leverage its acquisition of Nuvia and a team of ex-Apple chip architects to create leading performance for battery-powered devices. Amon also anticipates significant revenue growth from China, despite political tensions, and is open to licensing Nuvia's designs for cloud computing data centers.

title: Cadence Report Reveals Consumers’ Perception of Hyperconnectivity
summary: A new report from Cadence Design Systems Inc. indicates that a majority of consumers anticipate hyperconnectivity driven by hyperscale computing will positively affect their lives within five years. The report, "Hyperconnectivity & You – A Roadmap for the Consumer Experience," highlights key themes of confidence, convenience, and collaboration, underscoring the importance of data transparency, device security, and seamless integration of technology in consumer electronics, automotive, and healthcare sectors. Despite relatively low awareness of hyperscale computing, consumers expect significant positive impacts, particularly on mobile phones.

title: Texas Instruments to buy semiconductor factory in $900 million deal
summary: Texas Instruments announced it will acquire Micron Technology Inc.'s semiconductor factory in Lehi, Utah, for $900 million in cash. This acquisition will be TI's fourth 300-millimeter wafer facility, strengthening its manufacturing capabilities and supply chain control amid a global chip shortage. The company expects the plant to begin generating revenue in the first quarter of 2023, following an investment of approximately $75 million per quarter in 2022.

title: Is the AMD Ryzen 7 5800X good for gaming?
summary: The article evaluates the AMD Ryzen 7 5800X for gaming, concluding that it is not a good value due to its high price and performance that is similar to much cheaper alternatives like the Ryzen 5 5600X. It highlights that more CPU cores generally do not equate to significantly better gaming performance, and the 5800X's slight performance gains and limited overclocking potential don't justify its cost. The author recommends the AMD Ryzen 5 5600X as a superior choice for gamers based on its price-to-performance ratio.

title: Intel Restructuring: Navin Shenoy Out; New Software, GPU Units
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger has announced a major restructuring of the company, leading to the departure of top data center executive Navin Shenoy. The Data Platform Group is being split into two new business units, and two new divisions, the Software and Advanced Technology Group and the Accelerated Computing Systems and Graphics Group, are being formed. These changes aim to accelerate Intel's pace in regaining technology leadership, with new leaders appointed to head the reorganized groups.

title: Longtime Intel exec Navin Shenoy leaves as chipmaker restructures data center business
summary: Longtime Intel executive Navin Shenoy is departing the company as CEO Pat Gelsinger implements a major restructuring of its critical data center business, creating two new units. The Data Platform Group is being split into a Datacenter and AI group led by Sandra Rivera, and a Network and Edge Group led by Nick McKeown. Additionally, Intel is forming a Software and Advanced Technology Group and an Accelerated Computing Systems and Graphics Group, led by Greg Lavender and Raja Koduri respectively, to better compete with rivals like Nvidia, Arm Ltd., Qualcomm Corp., and Advanced Micro Devices Inc.

title: A big stock award helped a CEO jump to the top of the list of highest paid female execs
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su has become the highest-paid female executive in the Bay Area, largely due to a substantial $42 million stock award. This achievement has placed her at the top of the list, contrasting with last year's top two female executives who did not appear on this year's ranking. The report highlights the significant impact of stock awards on executive compensation.

title: Intel to work with India’s Reliance Jio on 5G network technology
summary: Intel Corp announced a partnership with India's Reliance Jio to co-develop 5G networking technology. This collaboration stems from Intel's venture capital unit's $250 million investment in Jio Platforms last year. The companies will focus on "co-innovations" for Reliance Jio's 5G radio-access network.

title: Kopin Pancake Optics to ‘Reshape’ MR Headsets
summary: Kopin Corp has developed fully-plastic Pancake optics designed to significantly improve virtual, augmented, and mixed reality headsets. These new optics offer magnified image quality with a thinner and lighter form factor, aiming to overcome the bulkiness that has hindered consumer adoption. Kopin has filed multiple patents for this technology, which promises to make MR headsets much lighter and more compact.

title: Rambus in two deals for datacentre interface
summary: Rambus has acquired AnalogX and PLDA to strengthen its position in data center interface IP, particularly for the Compute Express Link (CXL) standard. These acquisitions will accelerate Rambus' roadmap for PCIe 6.0 and CXL 3.0 solutions and bolster its CXL Memory Interconnect Initiative, aiming to develop next-generation memory interfaces for high-speed data center connectivity. The deals are expected to enhance Rambus' offerings for AI/ML and 5G applications and contribute to a paradigm shift in data center architectures.

title: Rambus Advances New Era of Data Center Architecture with CXL™ Memory Interconnect Initiative
summary: Rambus Inc. announced the CXL Memory Interconnect Initiative to develop semiconductor solutions for advanced data center architectures, focusing on memory expansion and pooling. This initiative aims to maximize performance, improve efficiency, and reduce system costs in data centers by leveraging Rambus' expertise in high-speed interfaces, embedded security, and server memory buffers. The acquisitions of PLDA and AnalogX are noted as key accelerants for Rambus' CXL roadmap and market leadership in this domain.

title: Invest in ETFs
summary: VanEck offers a variety of ETFs covering timeless themes like global equity, gold miners, and real estate, as well as smart themes such as semiconductors, video gaming, esports, and hydrogen. Each ETF is designed to support different investment goals but comes with specific risks that investors should carefully assess against their individual objectives. The article emphasizes conducting due diligence by referring to relevant documentation like the prospectus and Key Information Document (KID) before investing.

title: Opinion: AMD’s stock has been left behind, but not for long — here’s why
summary: The article argues that Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) stock is a good buy despite its significant past gains, as it hasn't fully rebounded from a recent dip unlike other semiconductor stocks like Nvidia. The author attributes this potential for future growth to AMD's new cutting-edge products and a key acquisition.

title: AMD's new Radeon PRO W6000 Series graphics bring professional power
summary: AMD has launched its new Radeon PRO W6000 series workstation graphics cards, built on the RDNA 2 architecture, offering significant performance improvements over previous generations. The top-tier Radeon PRO W6800 is available immediately, while the Radeon PRO W6600 and W6600M models are set to release later in the year, targeting demanding professional workloads. These GPUs feature advancements like AMD Infinity Cache and Smart Access Memory, delivering up to 79% faster performance.

title: Dell announces new AMD-based Integrated Systems for Azure Stack HCI
summary: Dell Technologies Inc. has launched new AMD-based configurations for its Dell EMC Integrated Systems for Microsoft Azure Stack HCI, designed to handle more complex workloads and offer enhanced performance. These systems feature AMD EPYC 2nd generation CPUs and incorporate advanced security features from both AMD and Dell. Additionally, software updates aim to simplify provisioning and delivery tasks for IT engineers by pre-installing the Azure Stack HCI operating system and integrating OpenManage software with Microsoft Windows Admin Center.

title: Samsung Elec, SK hynix’s memory supremacy challenged by Micron tech advance
summary: Micron Technology Inc. is challenging the memory supremacy of Samsung Electronics and SK hynix by advancing its 1α node-based LPDDR4x DRAM and 176-layer 3D NAND flash mass production. Micron's strategic moves include expanding its A3 DRAM facility and hiring experienced engineers, while Korean competitors are perceived to be lagging due to delayed commercialization and a focus on non-memory chips. This indicates a potential shift in the global memory chip market landscape.

title: AMD extends FidelityFX Super Resolution to RX 470 and RX 480
summary: AMD is extending its FidelityFX Super Resolution (FSR) technology to older graphics cards, specifically the Radeon RX 470 and RX 480 GPUs, dating back to 2016. This digital upscaling technology is designed to improve game performance and visuals without requiring significant processing power, and it will also work with a wide range of other AMD and some NVIDIA GeForce cards. FSR is expected to launch on June 22, 2021, offering performance boosts for both high-end and older hardware.

title: AMD shows how FidelityFX Super Resolution beats out NVIDIA's DLSS
summary: AMD announced FidelityFX Super Resolution (FSR) at Computex 2021, an image upscaling technology designed to boost frame rates and resolution. FSR directly competes with NVIDIA's DLSS but offers broader compatibility, supporting a wide range of AMD GPUs and even some NVIDIA GeForce cards. The technology, which provides up to a 2.5 times increase in performance mode, is expected to launch on June 22, 2021.

title: Intel vs. AMD — should you buy either stock now?
summary: This article contrasts Intel and AMD, two dominant players in the processor market, from an investment perspective. While AMD has shown significant outperformance under CEO Lisa Su, Intel remains the largest provider of core processors for PCs and servers, boasting a substantial R&D budget and strong cash flow. The piece questions which stock is a better buy for investors, acknowledging Intel's new CEO Pat Gelsinger's efforts to diversify and fend off AMD's market share gains.

title: Intel vs. AMD — should you buy either stock now?
summary: This article analyzes the long-standing rivalry between Intel and AMD in the core processor market. While AMD has shown significant market-share growth and superior stock performance, Intel remains a dominant force with a large R&D budget and strong cash flow. The piece explores the investment merits of each company for those considering buying either stock.

title: Oracle debuts its first Arm-based cloud instances
summary: Oracle has launched its first Arm-based cloud instances, OCI Ampere A1 Compute, offering customers more flexibility and high performance at lower costs for general-purpose and cloud-native workloads. This move signifies Oracle's increased investment in the Arm ecosystem, providing a compelling alternative to x86-based instances and competing with rival cloud providers by offering attractive pricing and scaling options. The company is also expanding developer resources and tools to encourage Arm-based application development on its cloud platform, including free tier offerings and a new development stack.

title: Putting the Chip Shortage into the Context of Long-Term Trends
summary: The article analyzes the current global semiconductor shortage, attributing it to supply chain rigidities, high barriers to entry, and geopolitical tensions exacerbated by COVID-19. It highlights the long-term trends driving increased semiconductor demand, such as 5G, AI, and electric vehicles, and discusses how governments and companies are responding to secure future supply chains and potentially re-shore manufacturing.

title: Lisa Su Secures 731 Million Votes In AMD Election – Talks About Tight Supply Chain
summary: Dr. Lisa Su, CEO of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), received an overwhelming 732 million votes in favor of her re-election to the company's board of directors during their annual shareholder meeting. This strong support comes as AMD announced a $4 billion share buyback program, the first since 2001, indicating management confidence in its financial position. Additionally, Dr. Su addressed the tight semiconductor supply chain, expressing optimism about AMD's ability to meet its 50% annual revenue growth target for 2021 through strong partnerships.

title: AMD CEO predicts supply of TSMC-built chips to improve
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su addressed current chip shortages, stating they are cyclical and not a "disaster," despite the semiconductor firm's increasingly tough path. Under Su's leadership, AMD has seen significant growth, with its market value surging to over US$90 billion, leading to a recent US$4 billion stock-repurchase plan. She emphasized the competitive nature of the market and AMD's ambitions amidst accelerated demand for computing resources due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: The TJX Companies (TJX) Q1 2022 Earnings: Key financials and quarterly highlights
summary: The TJX Companies reported strong financial results for Q1 2022, with net income reaching $533.9 million, or $0.44 per share, reversing a net loss from the prior year. Net sales significantly increased by 126% to $10.1 billion. CEO Ernie Herrman expressed optimism about the company's strong positioning post-health crisis and its opportunities for global market share expansion.

title: ADI Infographics: All you need to know about Analog Devices Q2 2021 earnings results
summary: Analog Devices, Inc. (ADI) reported strong Q2 2021 financial results, with total revenues increasing 26% to $1.66 billion and record revenue in the Industrial and Automotive markets. The company's net income for the quarter was $422 million, or $1.14 per share, significantly up from $267 million, or $0.72 per share, in Q2 2020.

title: Mythic Raises $70 Million in Series C Funding Led by BlackRock and Hewlett Packard Enterprise
summary: Mythic, a pioneering analog AI processor company, announced it has raised $70 million in Series C funding. This round was led by BlackRock and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), bringing Mythic's total funding to $165.2 million. The new capital will be used to accelerate mass production of its AI inference solutions, expand customer support, and develop its next-generation hardware and software.

title: Intel Launches New 11th Gen Core for Mobile
summary: Intel Corporation (INTC) announced the global launch of its 11th Generation Intel Core H-series mobile processors, code-named "Tiger Lake-H," on May 11, 2021. The flagship Intel Core i9-11980HK, based on 10nm SuperFin process technology, delivers speeds up to 5.0GHz, offering industry-leading mobile performance for gaming, content creation, and business professionals with up to eight cores and 16 threads, and PCIe Gen 4 support. The release also includes new Intel vPro H-series and Intel Xeon W-11000 series mobile processors, powering over 80 enthusiast laptop designs this year.

title: STMicroelectronics Tackles the EV Industry with GaN
summary: STMicroelectronics is focusing on gallium nitride (GaN) technology to enhance efficiency in electric vehicle applications, recognizing its superiority over silicon in high-power scenarios. The company has released a new family of GaN devices called STi2GaN, specifically designed for the automotive industry, which integrates power stages, drivers, and protection within GaN and SiP solutions. This move aligns with STMicroelectronics' earlier commitment to invest in wide-bandgap semiconductors for carbon neutrality goals.

title: Samsung to jump into laptop processor market with Exynos chip in H2
summary: Samsung Electronics is set to enter the laptop processor market in the second half of this year with a premium Exynos chip, targeting the rapidly growing global laptop market. The new Exynos chip will feature a GPU developed with AMD, focusing on improved computing power and battery efficiency with 5-nanometer processing technology. Samsung's move follows other tech giants like Apple and Qualcomm, who have also developed laptop-grade chipsets, as the company seeks to compete with market leader Intel.

title: Microsoft pulls Windows 10 AMD driver causing PCs not to boot
summary: Microsoft has withdrawn an AMD driver from Windows Update after reports that it caused Windows 10 PCs to fail to boot, displaying an "INACCESSIBLE BOOT DEVICE" error.
